metadata.sermon_start_end: A good deal of attention is being given nowadays to the language fof the Presidential campaign. It’s generally agreed that Mr. Dole has a problem with language. His lack of eloquence is such a handicap that novelist Mark Helprin was brought in to write some of his speeches. [...] May we open our lives to the Word of life this very day and receive from him the love from which we shall never be separated, for this life and for the life to come. Fides ex auditu. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon is not an exposition of Romans 10:17 but a topical speech about the concept of preaching itself. It uses the text as a 'biblical keyword' or 'idea' (Thesis 1.3) rather than a specific pericope to be unfolded. It fails to identify what is in this text that can be found nowhere else.
quotes: In the tenth chapter of the Epistle to the Romans (v. 17), the apostle Paul writes, 'So faith comes from what is heard...'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Abandon the topical lecture on 'the power of language' and focus exclusively on the specific context of Romans 10—the necessity of the herald in the economy of salvation.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exegesis. The preacher does not address the original context of Paul’s argument regarding Israel and the Gentiles. The use of 'Greek and Hebrew' (Thesis 2) is absent; the text is merely a springboard for a theology of the Word.
quotes: That is how the gospel spread. The Christian faith swept through the Mediterranean world because God gave the early Christians a new language...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explain the specific meaning of 'akoe' (hearing/report) in the context of Paul’s rhetorical questions in Romans 10:14-15.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely focused on the state of the church and the 'crisis of preaching' rather than the life of the hearer. While it mentions the zeitgeist (cyberspace, presidential campaigns), these are used as illustrations for the sermon's theme rather than concrete applications of the text to the hearer's spiritual life.
quotes: In this age of images, with our children and grandchildren certain to be more familiar with cyberspace than with books...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move from the general problem of 'language' to the concrete responsibility of the hearer to respond to the proclaimed Word.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is little exposition of the text itself, there is no movement where the hearer is 'expounded' together with the text. The sermon remains a meta-discourse about preaching.
quotes: Preaching is a human activity, but it is derived from God. It has nothing to do with the religious accomplishment...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the specific demands of the Romans text into the description of the contemporary human condition.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present in the 'crisis of confidence' and the 'flawed and sinful' nature of the preacher. Redemption is found in the 'Word of life.' However, these are treated as general theological truths rather than being drawn from the specific misery/redemption dynamic of Romans 10.
quotes: God has summoned human beings, flawed and sinful, to be his apostles...
receive from him the love from which we shall never be separated
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Make the 'misery' more specific to the text: the impossibility of faith without the external Word.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon lacks the 'seriousness of being lost' (Thesis 6). It ends on a note of general love and 'never being separated,' which borders on the 'liberal tradition' Dekker warns against where man cannot be lost.
quotes: receive from him the love from which we shall never be separated, for this life and for the life to come.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of *not* hearing or rejecting the Word, which is inherent in the 'two ways' and the context of Romans.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the strongest point. The preacher correctly identifies Christ as the 'telos' and the 'Word made flesh.' The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the 'risen, reigning, living Jesus Christ.'
quotes: He is present in the Word, because he is himself the Word.
the risen, reigning, living Jesus Christ has promised to be present in power.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is the telos of the *text's specific message*, not just a general theological conclusion.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes (1850 words), the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth' because it spends too much time on secular anecdotes (Churchill, Dole) rather than scriptural depth.
quotes: We shall not flag or fail. We shall go on to the end. We shall fight in France... [long quote]
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Reduce the length of secular quotes to allow for more intensive biblical exposition.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions more as a 'speech about the gospel' or a 'theological lecture on homiletics' than a sermon as defined by Dekker. It fails to provide an exposition of a specific Bible passage, opting instead for a topical treatment of 'The Word.' It lacks the 'two ways' and the necessary length for depth.
strengths: Strong Christological focus (Thesis 7), correctly identifying Christ as the active agent in the Word.
Adequate understanding of the 'acoustical' nature of revelation (Thesis 1.2).
weaknesses: Failure to treat the Bible passage as a specific pericope; it treats Romans 10:17 as a general motto.
Excessive use of secular illustrations (Churchill, politics) that do not serve the exposition of the text.
Absence of the 'two ways' (Thesis 6), resulting in a lack of existential urgency.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s criteria, this is not a sermon. It is a speech about preaching. It fails the formal requirement of being an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage' because it ignores the specific context and unique contribution of the chosen text.
